channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: 6.2-Magnitude Earthquake Rattles Italy, Killing Dozens
item.description: Roughly 40 strong quakes in the nation’s center were reported over a three-hour period, officials said, and tremors awakened residents in Rome, nearly 100 miles away.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: Turkish Military Begins Major Offensive Into Syria in Fight Against ISIS
item.media:description: A Turkish Army tank driving toward Syria on Wednesday.
item.description: The operation began hours before Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. was set to meet with President Recep Tayyip Erdogan to discuss tensions raised by the failed coup.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Kurds Close to Control of Northeast Syria Province, Portending a Shift in the War
item.media:description: Kurdish fighters in Hasaka, Syria, on Tuesday. Militias groups there have signed a cease-fire with the government.
item.description: A cease-fire with the Syrian government puts Kurdish militias much closer to control of Hasaka Province, which would be the third lost by President Bashar al-Assad.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: 1.2 Million Iraqis Could Be Uprooted in Mosul Battle, U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations refugee agency is scrambling to build encampments for those who will be displaced in a fight to rout the Islamic State from Mosul.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Egyptians Take to the Streets Again, Now in Workout Gear
item.media:description: A rooftop CrossFit gym in Cairo. “The young people can’t go out demonstrating, but they can go out to run,” said Ramy A. Saleh, who pioneered CrossFit in Egypt.
item.media:credit: Sima Diab for The New York Times
item.description: For a country where smoking is everywhere and obesity and diabetes are rampant, a new fitness revolution has been a stark departure.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: ‘No One Is Safe’: Zimbabwe Threatens to Seize Farms of Party Defectors
item.media:description: Agrippah Mutambara at his farm on the outskirts of Bindura, Zimbabwe. Like dozens of political figures who have fallen out of favor, he is facing the seizure of his farm.
item.description: In a nation where land is used as a tool of control, many former officials who were beneficiaries of seizures of white-owned farms now find themselves potential victims.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: John Kerry Warns Nigerian Military on Human Rights Abuses
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry speaking in Nairobi, Kenya, this week.
item.description: The military has been criticized for detaining, torturing or killing civilians as it hunts the Islamic militant group Boko Harm.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STEIN and DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: In Arts and Culture, a ‘New’ Mexico Embraces Its Roots
item.media:description: Natalia Lafourcade is a Mexican singer and songwriter who decided “it was time to connect back with my origins.”
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.description: Many emerging artists and trendsetters are drawing inspiration from within Mexican culture and society rather than looking abroad.
item.dc:creator: PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: North Korea Test-Fires Missile From Submarine
item.media:description: South Korean news programs showed video from the North’s missile test.
item.description: The test represents a significant advance in the North’s ability to strike American and allied forces.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Bomb Kills an American Soldier Near Besieged Afghan City
item.media:description: Afghan security forces preparing for battle against Taliban militants in the Charkhab area of Kunduz Province on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Bashir Khan Safi/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: United States forces have been drawn more heavily into the defense of Lashkar Gah, the Helmand provincial capital under direct threat by the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: An Australian Dictionary Makes ‘Shirt-front’ and ‘Budgie Smuggler’ Official
item.media:description: Swimmers wearing “budgie smugglers” at Maroubra Beach in Sydney, Australia.
item.description: The new edition, the first update since 1988, lists 16,000 idioms popular in Australia and includes terms from more than 100 indigenous languages.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: 6.2-Magnitude Earthquake Shakes Italy, Killing at Least 10
item.description: More than 39 strong earthquakes were reported over a three-hour period, officials said, and tremors awakened residents in Rome nearly 100 miles to the southwest of the epicenter.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO and CHRISTOPHER MELE

item.title: The U.S. Election Is in Its Final 11 Weeks. Canadians Wonder, ‘Why So Long?’
item.media:description: Justin Trudeau leaving a campaign rally with members of his family in Brampton, Ontario, in 2015.
item.description: In Canada, the long slog would just be starting, and many of our neighbors to the north think the U.S. election cycle, close to a two-year marathon, is a waste of time.
item.dc:creator: DANIEL VICTOR

item.title: Ethiopian Runner Won’t Return Home, but Doesn’t Know Where to Go
item.media:description: Feyisa Lilesa of Ethiopia made a protest gesture as he crossed the finish line in the marathon at the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday.
item.description: Feyisa Lilesa, the silver medal winner in the Rio Olympics marathon who made an antigovernment gesture, said he feared punishment if he were to go home.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Brain Scans of Brazilian Babies Show Array of Zika Effects
item.media:description: Images show the damage inflicted on the heads of twin girls born with the Zika virus.
item.description: The images show that the virus can inflict serious damage to many different parts of the fetal brain beyond microcephaly, the condition of unusually small heads.
item.dc:creator: PAM BELLUCK

item.title: China’s Crackdown on Dissent Could Lead to Unrest, U.N. Adviser Says
item.description: Philip Alston warns that the Communist Party’s tight grip on civil society is undermining basic human rights.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Rodrigo Duterte’s Police Chief Blames Suspects for Toll in Philippine Drug War
item.media:description: The scene of a shootout between the police and a drug suspect in Manila last week. The number of deaths since the antidrug campaign began on July 1 has jumped to 1,916, the national police chief said.
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.description: Chief Ronald dela Rosa told a Senate hearing that a spike in deaths was being caused by suspects who choose to battle officers instead of surrendering.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Sangke Grasslands Journal: Camping in the Spartan Nomad Lands of Tibet. With a Cocktail. And a Sauna.
item.media:description: Yidam Kyap, left, who helps run Norden Camp, with guests including Tibetan monks, around a bonfire last month.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: “Glamping,” or glamorous camping, has arrived in the vast, rugged region, as part of an ambitious social enterprise by a Tibetan-American family.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Court Upholds Doping-Related Ban on Russia at Paralympics
item.description: The Court of Arbitration for Sport rejected an appeal by Russia, confirming that none of the country’s athletes would participate in the Games that begin on Sept. 7.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ

item.title: Irish Woman Live-Tweets Trip to Get Abortion in England
item.media:description: A march for changes in abortion law in Dublin in 2012.
item.description: The anonymous woman, accompanied by a friend, set out to highlight the restrictions placed on the procedure in Ireland, putting new pressure on the government to respond to calls for change.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Boko Haram Leader Is Wounded in Airstrike, Nigeria’s Military Says
item.media:description: A poster advertising the search for the Boko Haram leader Abubakar Shekau in the Nigerian village of Baga in 2013.
item.description: The armed forces have claimed to have killed Abubakar Shekau in the past, and the latest report was impossible to independently confirm.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: After Failed Coup, Turkey Enjoys a Rare Period of Unity
item.media:description: Members of various political parties gathered in Taksim Square in Istanbul last month to condemn the coup attempt against President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
item.description: Many Turks have put aside political differences after a failed military uprising — although some may be motivated by fear in the wake of the president’s purge of suspected political enemies.
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Sports of The Times: Rio Games Highlight Problems With the Olympic Model
item.media:description: The waters around Rio de Janeiro were a source of concern for many before the Olympics, and government promises to construct sewage-treatment centers to drastically reduce the pollution went unfulfilled.
item.description: The problems that cities face in hosting the Olympics, like being left with immediately obsolete venues, call for organizers to develop a more sustainable approach.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL POWELL

item.title: What in the World: What Poor Nations Need to Get By: Money From Migrants
item.description: Remittances from workers abroad are so important to some countries that one-third of their economies may depend on it, the World Bank says.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: What in the World: On Sundays in Senegal, Surf’s Up for the Sheep
item.media:description: From left, Fallou Gueye, 14; Ousseynou Cissé, 21; Seymour Gueye, 13; and Aboukhadre Sene, 13, washing a ram this month at Yoff Beach in Dakar, Senegal.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Washing livestock in the Atlantic is a weekly tradition, even on the crowded beaches near the capital, Dakar, that the human swimmers favor.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Gridlock Comes to Kuala Lumpur
item.description: One of the growing pains of Malaysia’s economic prosperity is that its capital’s traffic problem is reaching critical mass.
item.dc:creator: TASH AW

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Why Do I Love Bollywood?
item.description: India’s film industry reflects the global South’s troubling transformations in a way few other art forms can.
item.dc:creator: AATISH TASEER

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turkey’s Great Purge
item.media:description: Supporters of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan burned an effigy in Istanbul last month of Fethullah Gulen, a United States-based imam and the leader of the movement said to be behind the attempted coup.
item.description: Is President Erdogan crushing his critics or addressing a real threat to the Turkish state?
item.dc:creator: MUSTAFA AKYOL
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Photo Editors’ Notebook: What Makes the Image of Omran Daqneesh Extraordinary?
item.media:description: The front page of The New York Times on August 19 featured a photograph by Mahmoud Raslan of a 5-year-old boy who was rescued after an airstrike in Aleppo, Syria.
item.description: “It’s a difficult question for even the most seasoned photo editor to answer.”
item.dc:creator: CRAIG ALLEN

item.title: Nigeria Is Freeing Children From Boko Haram, Then Locking Them Up
item.media:description: Displaced people taking shelter from the rain at a camp in Maiduguri, Nigeria, in June.
item.media:credit: Jane Hahn for The New York Times
item.description: Civilians, and even infants, are ending up in military detention centers as Nigeria holds people it suspects of being sympathizers of the Islamist extremist group.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
